content.description:
Follow the crack system in the center of the main wall for two pitches of fun, pretty well-protected climbing.

P1: climb around the bush and up fun crack and face moves to the first Zig going right out the hand rail of the huge, broken block. Easy climbing takes you up under the big roof. Walk out to the left side of the roof, and follow the fun crack as it Zags back to the left. After 20' or so, the crack goes straight up on nice finger locks and hand jams up to a roof. Step right under the roof to a two bolt anchor.

P2: climb the slab, and crack up on the best looking/steepest rock to the big ledge. From there, climb a nice 5.8 crack in a corner for 20 feet to a two bolt anchor.

Do 2 raps with a 60m rope.
content.protection: A double set of cams with a set of nuts is more than enough gear.
content.location: Locate the crack in the center of the tallest wall at the crag. There is usually a small bush growing right in front of the first few moves.

content.description: A hard crux between 1st and 2nd bolts leads to technical thin climbing up high. It is a pretty good route even though it is short. This is a bit dirty but will clean up with traffic - the rock is solid, it is mostly just dirt.
content.protection:
6 bolts to an anchor - two bolts with a biner on one. You could easily go up to the anchor of

Black Keys

to lower if you prefer.
content.location:
It is the furthest right route, one right of

Black Keys

.

content.description: Climb a hard sequence pulling the low roof to a long, good, but easy slab.
content.location:
Just left of

The Black Keys

, it is the left line in the photo on

The Black Keys

.

content.description: Climb the right side of a large chimney. Stem a bit through the first two bolts until you can commit to the face. The crux is up high.
content.location:
It is on the lower section of the cliff, two routes left of

The Black Keys

(just around the corner from the bolted lines in that picture).

content.description: This has a technical start and climbs good rock. It is probably the best warm -up at the cliff.
Begin with easy climbing to the third bolt, then climb a hard crux section from the 3rd to 5th bolts (4th clip is tough), and finish with a technical but easier top. This is a good climb.
content.location: It shares anchors with the 10+ and starts about 10 feet left in somewhat broken rock. This goes to an obvious, clean, steep section of black rock about 20 feet up.

content.description: Interesting techy climbing for about 6 bolts leads to the crux through steep black rock and over a bulge. A few moves on blind holds turn the roof on the right, then get a rest, and it gets easier to the anchors.
content.location: Just right of the obvious arete climb, trend slightly right through black rock. There are currently two starts - the left line is the one (the right start may be removed in the future).

content.description:
Climb up the low-angle face for 2 bolts, then work up a series of slightly overhanging moves in the corner to a staggered two-bolt anchor.

This route could be continued through a powerful sequence past 1 more bolt to chain anchors at the top of the cliff.
content.protection: 7 bolts to the lower anchor and 1 more bolt to the upper anchor.
content.location: It is the rightmost route in the uppermost tier. Start above the tree with the fixed line attached to it.

content.description:
P1: thin moves off the ground climb up to a bolt in a open book corner. Climb up to the big roof, and follow the crack around the right side of the roof. Follow the crack with face holds up to another bolt that protects fun slab moves to a two bolt anchor.

P2: climb up and right from the anchor, and follow the line of bolts up the slab to another two bolt anchor, 7 or 8 bolts.

Do two raps with a 60 meter rope. Tie knots in the rope for the first rap, the second anchor is right at the ends of the rope.
content.protection: A single set of cams and a set of nuts and 12 action clips.
content.location:
Start on the slab in-between the

Zig Zag

route and the bushy crack that splits the wall.

content.description: Climb up a low-angle ramp to four bolts of climbing in a dihedral before moving left into a roof. The anchors are about 8' above the roof.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 1 #0.5 BD cam (1" piece), and a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: It is the left bolted line in the uppermost tier. Start up low-angle ramp to flake feature in a left-facing dihedral.

content.description: Start in the jungle chimney, and traverse right across a slab to the first bolt. It is a long way, but it is easy and safe. Head up a vertical wall with a definitive crux at the 3rd bolt. Finish through a roof (large holds, not too bad). The crux is hard and fun, the rest of the route is much easier - never more than 11a.
content.location:
It is the right route in the alcove next to

Frequent Flyer

.

climbs.name: Frequent Flyer
climbs.fa: Allen Riling, bolted by Dusty Bender

content.description: Start directly above the jungle chimney. Fun, technical 5.11 climbing through about 10 bolts leads to a hard crux pulling a lieback roof near the top.
content.protection: 12 bolts with a permadraw at the crux.
content.location: It is the left route in the upper alcove.

content.description: The Black Keys has fun, technical crimping on holds about the size of the black keys on a piano for the first 4 bolts and then follows more bolts up a fun slab/face.
content.location: Close to where the trail meets the wall, start on a sketchy looking, broken block...it's not coming out, though.

content.description: Interesting, technical climbing leads up to a roof. There is a clear crux move getting to the roof - kind of hard to read but not too bad once you find the holds. Turn the roof on big holds, and continue on easy but runout climbing to the anchor.
content.location: It ascends the obvious arete route up the hill, just before the alcove. The route climbs on the right side of the arete, turning a roof up high (right side).
